byline.contributor: Adam Wu contributed research from Shenzhen, and Kiki Zhao from Beijing.
byline.original: By CHRIS BUCKLEY and AUSTIN RAMZY

abstract: Deadly landslide outside Shenzhen, China, is seen as inevitable result of constant, largely unregulated dumping of construction debris in area experiencing development boom; rescuers report finding one survivor and two bodies as families wait for news of missing relatives.
lead_paragraph: Two bodies have been recovered from the site of Sunday’s landslide in the southern Chinese boomtown of Shenzhen, where some saw the disaster as inevitable but where alarms got little attention.

headline.main: Before Shenzhen Landslide, Many Saw Warning Signs as Debris Swelled
headline.print_headline: Dumping Day and Night in Shenzhen, Ignoring the Growing Peril

snippet: Two bodies have been recovered from the site of Sunday’s landslide in the southern Chinese boomtown of Shenzhen, where some saw the disaster as inevitable but where alarms got little attention.
